repnme.cdata!:
Iran - Northern Cities Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Northern Cities Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project for Iran were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            realism in project design should be reflected by the
            project's complete assessment of all the local
            realities on the ground during project preparation. In the
            case of the current project, this should have translated
            into evidence of adequate completion of preparation work for
            land acquisition and detailed estimates of engineering
            designs; preparation of bidding documents for the first year
            prepared by the borrower. The construction of wastewater
            treatment facilities cannot be fully implemented in five
            years. Institutional strengthening has focused on capacity
            building and training which was very important for the
            project. However, although sector coordination was
            recognized as a possible problem area at the time of project
            preparation/appraisal, it was not given due consideration.
            Coordination among the various stakeholders should be seen
            as an aspect of institutional development and an important
            determinant for project results. There is also a need to
            identify indicators that can monitor variables that can be
            directly attributed to the project. The working ratio is not
            always the most appropriate indicator for financial
            sustainability as there are many external factors that
            affect it such as cost of materials (steel, cement and
            others) and energy. A utility could be improving certain
            efficiencies but strong increases in market prices will
            affect the expenses considerably.

repnme.cdata!:
Iran - Northern Cities Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Northern Cities Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project will enhance the quality of life in the
            four northern cities of Rasht, Anzali, Sari and Babol, and
            will improve the operational efficiency and financial
            sustainability of the Water and Wastewater Companies (WWCs).
            The project consist of the following 10 components:
            component 1) will extend and improve Rasht's collection
            network. Component 2) will improve the service provision in
            Rasht through regulating the pressure and availability of
            water in the distribution network, as well as reduction in
            losses due to leakage. Component 3) will extend and improve
            Anzali's collection network. Component 4) will
            rehabilitate and extend Anzali's water distribution
            network with 155 km of primary and secondary distribution
            network. Component 5) will provide technical assistance,
            training and consultant services for institutional
            development and environmental management plan, Technical
            Support Unit (TSU), engineering design and construction
            supervision. Component 6) includes construction of a
            wastewater collection and treatment system in Sari.
            Component 7) will extend and rehabilitate Sari's
            distribution network. Component 8) will include: (i) the
            provision of 16,300 new house connections, (ii) the
            construction of approximately 130 km of laterals,
            interceptors, and trunk mains, and (iii) 6 pump and lift
            stations. Component 9) includes: (i) the construction of a 20,000

Iran - Northern Cities Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

repnme.cdata!:
Iran - Northern Cities Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF)
            prepared for the Northern Cities Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project explicitly includes the cities covering four major
            cities of the southern Caspian provinces of Gilan and
            Mazandaran: Anzali, Rasht, Babol and Sari. The project seeks
            to enhance environmental and health conditions, and its
            development objectives further include improvement in the
            quality of life, and poverty alleviation; increased coverage
            of sanitation services, and, implementation of a pilot
            program to include hygiene and sanitation practices towards
            improving the health conditions of the targeted population.
            In view of the project's infrastructure development
            works, land acquisition, and the resulting resettlement
            issues will take place; therefore, this resettlement policy
            framework looks at the estimated population to be displaced,
            reviews the country's legislation and the Bank's
            operational directive on involuntary resettlement, and
            provides resettlement guidance and the compensation measures
            to be followed. There are two ways to fund compensation:
            through budgetary provision in the recurrent budget, where
            the water authority (WWC) earns revenue (this is not
            normally the case in this project); or, where the need for
            expropriation has been foreseen in the five-year development
            plan (this is the case with most expropriations in this
            project). Expropriation takes place under Article IX of the
            law of expropriation of Land in the public interest. Based
            on public consultations, and in agreement with project
            affected persons, compensation will be paid in cash at
            market values for loss of land, crops, or physical
            structures, as well as other assets lost. Monitoring
            criteria will be in place to ensure compliance with this
            RAP, as will grievance mechanisms should conflict occur.
